summary: in 2003, a reassorted H1N2 swine influenza virus subtype appeared and became prevalent in swine. the reassortant H1N2 subtype was characterised genetically and the infection dynamics compared to an “avian-like” H1N1 virus by an experimental infection study. the reassorted “avian-like” H1N2 subtype is a reassortant between circulating swine “avian-like” H1N1 and H3N2. the Danish H1N2 has an “avian-like” H1 and differs from most other reported H1N2 viruses. European H3N2 SIV are human-avian reassortants retaining the HA and NA genes from human H3N2 virus. the remaining gene segments originate from “avian-like” H1N1 SIV [6]. H1N2, which is the most recently recognized new European SIV subtype, was first reported from Great Britain in 1995 [7] “avian-like” H1 has been reported previously from france and Italy. the reassorted “avian-like” H1N2 subtype was first recognized in a lung tissue sample from a pig with coughing, fever and panting. the detected virus (A/swine/Denmark/12687/2003(H1N2) had an “avian-like” H1, and this reassorted H1N2 subtype has since been detected from lung tissue and the identity of the HA gene between the Danish H1N2 viruses and the reference virus A/swine/Scotland/410440/1994(H1N2) and contemporary European human-like H1N2 viruses from Germany was 73%. the nucleotide sequence comparisons of all gene segments are shown in Table 3 and phylogenetic trees for the internal genes are shown in Figure 3. enmark/13608/2004(H1N2) had a very high nucleotide identity (HA gene 96%, NA gene 96%) to H1N2 reassortant viruses detected in 2009 and 2010. seven N-glycosylation sites were predicted for A/swine/Denmark/13608/2004(H1N2) in the HA protein, whereas only 4 sites were predicted in A/swine/Denmark/12687/2003(H s of the Danish H1N2 viruses showed no indication of resistance to NA-inhibitors. all the Danish M sequences deduced resistance against amantadine. N1 followed by H1N2, group 2: H1N2 followed by H1N1 showed haptoglobin and CRP responses following each of the inoculations, peaking on PID 4 and 35 (group 1) or 4 and 39 (group 2). no SAA response was seen for group 2 after the H1N2 infection. results from the HI-test using A/swine/Denmark/19126/1993 (H1N1) as antigen. stapled lines indicate day of inoculation respectively post infection day (PID) 0 and PID 28. group 1 pigs (1–6) were reinoculated post inoculation (PID) 0 with A/swine/Denmark/19126/1993 (H1N1) and reinoculated PID 28 with A/swine/Denmark/10074/2004 (H1N2). Group 2 pigs (7–12) were inoculated post inoculation (PID) 0 with A/swine/Denmark/19126/1993 (H1 inoculated post inoculation (PID) 0 with A/swine/Denmark/10074/2004 (H1N2) and reinoculated PID 28 with A/swine/Denmark/19126/1993 (H1N1) showed virus excretions from PID 1 to PID 6–8. for the pigs in group 2 (H1N2 inoculated), the peak was approximately 6 times higher reaching 3.6 107 TCID50 the virus load was about 7-fold higher in the group of H1N1 infected pigs compared to the H1N2 infected pigs. however, this difference was not significant (p = 0.06). group 1 pigs were inoculated PID 0 with A/swine/Denmark/19126/1993 (H1N1) and group 2 pigs were inoculated PID 0 with A/swine/Denmark/10074/2004 (H1N2) analysis of sequences and phylogenetics Viruses included in the study are listed in Table 1 with GenBank accession numbers. the NA gene of the Danish H1N2 viruses clustered phylogenetically with concurrent Danish H3N2 viruses with an identity between 91–99%. the nucleotide sequence comparisons of all gene segments are shown in Table 3 and phylogenetic trees for the internal genes are shown in Figure 3. seven N-glycosylation sites (positions 28, 40, 71, 179, 291, 498, 557) were predicted for A/swine/Denmark/13608/2004(H1N2) in the HA protein. only 4 sites (positions 28, 40, 498, 557) were predicted in A/swine/Denmark/12687/2003(H1N2) included in the study Virus Subtype Passage history Sample material GenBank accession no. percentage identity of nucleotide sequences were calculated with CLC DNA Workbench version 6.8.1. the trees show the phylogenetic relationship of the reassorted Danish H1N2 swine influenza virus to representative Danish SIV. pigs inoculated with H1N1 on PID 0 and euthanized on day 4 (group 1) had consolidated lobules in the cranial lung lobes. in the left cranial lobes, approximately 80% of the tissue was consolidated, the middle lobes were approximately 40% consolidated and the accessory lobes were 20% consolidated. no SAA response was seen for group 2 after the H1N2 infection. however, these pigs did show an SAA response after the subsequent inoculation. difference between groups for all three acute phase proteins was not statistically significant. the stapled lines indicate day of inoculation respectively post infection day (PID) 0 and PID 28. influenza A virus RNA was detected in nasal swabs in both groups until day 7 after the 1st inoculation. group 1 pigs (7–12) were inoculated post inoculation (PID) 0 with A/swine/Denmark/19126/1993 (H1N1) and reinoculated PID 28 with A/swine/Denmark/10074/2004 (H1N2) pigs (7–12) were inoculated post inoculation (PID) 0 with A/swine/Denmark/10074/2004 (H1 pigs in group 1 (H1N1 inoculated), the virus titre peaked with an average of 5.8 106 TCID50 equivalents on PID 3. in group 2, two nasal swabs from one pig were found to be positive with a virus load of 5.6 102 TCID50 equivalents on PID 29 and 1.9 102 TCID50 equivalents. group 1 pigs were inoculated post inoculation day (PID) 0 with H1N1. group 2 pigs were inoculated PID 0 with H1N2 (stapled line) the genes of the reassorted H1N2 virus had very high identity to contemporary H1N1 and H3N2 viruses circulating in most of Europe which have a human-like HA gene. the genes of the reassorted H1N2 virus apparently arose by two independent reassortment events. enmark/13608/2004(H1N2) had seven predicted glycosylation sites in the HA-protein compared to the A/swine/Denmark/12687/2003(H1N2) which had 4 sites. the virus was detected in Denmark for the first time in 2003, approximately 6–7 years before it was found in Sweden. the reassortant H1N2 virus may have been missed. the reassortment event happened between two Danish strains of H1N2 and H3N2. reassortment event subsequently spread to other European countries by export of living pigs. the NA gene of A/swine/Italy/2064/1999(H1N2) is closely related to that of concurrent Danish H3N2 viruses. however, the NA gene of A/swine/Italy/2064/1999(H1N2) may be a reassortment of avian-like H1N1 and A/swine/Scotland/4104/94(H1N2)-like viruses. there have been no further reports pigs elicited no clinical signs in response to experimental inoculation. the pigs were specific laboratory raised animals of high sanitary status free from the majority of pathogens known to cause disease in pigs. an antibody response was elicited after inoculation of the first virus isolate. the response was boosted when the pigs were re-inoculated with the second virus isolate. no SSA response to primary infection with H1N2 was seen. 20% of the circulating subtypes in Danish pigs (own unpublished observations) the reason for this is not known but it’s interesting that this virus has succeeded in spreading despite existing immunity against the H protein of the H1N1 subtypes that has been circulating in Denmark since the mid-1980s. gene sequences were aligned with MUSCLE using CLC DNA Workbench version 6.8.1. Neighbour Joining trees were calculated with a bootstrap value of 1000. pigs were randomly divided into two groups of 6 pigs, denoted group 1 and group 2. two pigs were euthanized on PID 4 with a titer of 105.9 TCID50 per ml. the remaining four pigs were re-inoculated with 4 ml of A/swine/Denmark/10074/2004 (H1N2). the experimental design was similar except that the pigs were inoculated on PID 0 with the H1N2 isolate. samples taken on PID 0 and 28 were collected prior to inoculation. at post mortem, samples were collected and frozen at -80°C. study was carried out in strict accordance with the Danish legislation on animal experiments. cross-reactivity of the anti human CRP antibody with porcine CRP was demonstrated. the detection limit was 1416 ng/mL (human equivalents) chicken erythrocytes were used as standard blood cells. a 1% suspension of erythrocytes in PBS with 0.005% gelatine was used. RNA purification RNA was purified from nasal swabs and lung tissue samples. the amplification temperature profile was 50°C for 30 min for reverse transcription followed by 95°C for 15 min and 45 cycles of 94°C for 20 s, 60°C for 20 s and 72°C for 30 s. the fluorescence signal was measured at 72°C during each PCR cycle and at each temperature increment step during the melting analysis. the real time RT-PCR was performed in a Rotor-Gene 3000 machine (Corbett Research, Australia) the amplification temperature profile was 50°C for 30 min for reverse transcription followed by 95°C for 5 min and 45 cycles of 95°C for 15 s, 55°C for 30 s and 72°C for 20 s. the fluorescence signal was measured at 55°C during each PCR cycle and at each temperature increment step during the melting analysis. Viruses Viruses were propagated in either Madin-Darby Canine Kidney Epithelial Cells (MDCK) or primary swine kidney cell cultures. isolation was achieved from routine diagnostic samples, nasal swabs or lung tissue samples. full genome sequencing of all 8 gene segments was performed as previously described by bragstad et al. 2005 [36] 30 known swine pathogens including porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2), porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (SIV), porcine respiratory coronavirus, Actinobacillus pleuropneumonia and mycoplasmas were used for the experiment. each group was housed in separate isolation units (biosafety level 3). blood samples obtained on PID 0 and 28 were left on ice to coagulate for 15 minutes and centrifuged at 3500 rpm for 10 minutes at 4°C. swabs were placed in 1 ml phosphate buffered saline (pH 7.5) and stored at -80°C until analysis. sandwich ELISA assay based on anti-human monoclonal antibodies. detection limit was 125 g/ml (porcine SAA equivalents) cross-reactivity of anti human CRP antibody with porcine CRP demonstrated previously. in the HI-test, 25 l PBS was added to each well of a microtitre plate. then 25 l of the antigen (4 HA units) were added to each well. the plate was shaken for 10 sec and incubated for 30 minutes at room temperature. RNA was stored at -80°C until analysis. RNA was extracted from all nasal swabs and lung tissue samples. all positive samples were further tested in a quantitative real time RT-PCR assay. real time RT-PCR was performed in a Rotor-Gene 3000 machine (Corbett Research, Australia) with a total reaction volume of 25 l using the RNA UltrasenseTM One-Step Quantitative RT-PCR System (Invitrogen), 5 l of extracted RNA, 0.4 M of forward primer, 1.0 M of FAM-labelled reverse primer, and 1.0 M of Cy5-labelled probe. a standard curve for the real time RT-PCR assay was obtained using a ten-fold dilution series made from an initial concentration of 107.8 TCID50 per ml of the virus A/swine/Denmark/1993 (H1N1). the efficiency of the PCR was 92% and the range of quantification spanned 6 log10 dilutions from dilution 10-1 to 10-7. study funded by the Danish Agriculture & Food Council, Axelborg.
